quiz.title: Unit 5: Energy & Power (Quiz 8)
quiz.subtitle: Identifying Types of Energy and Energy Changes
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A satellite orbits Earth at a constant speed. What type(s) of energy does the satellite possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The orbiting satellite has kinetic energy (orbital speed) and gravitational potential energy (distance from Earth).

questions.question: A tree branch hangs motionlessly above a river. What type(s) of energy does the branch possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The stationary branch at height has gravitational potential energy but no kinetic energy.

questions.question: A spring toy moves back and forth at its midpoint. What type(s) of energy does the toy possess at the midpoint?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: At the equilibrium midpoint, the spring toy has maximum speed (maximum kinetic energy) and minimum potential energy.

questions.question: A cannonball flies horizontally after being fired. What type(s) of energy does the cannonball possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The cannonball has kinetic energy (horizontal motion) and gravitational potential energy (height above ground).

questions.question: A skier is stationary at the top of a steep slope. What type(s) of energy does the skier possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The stationary skier at height has gravitational potential energy but no kinetic energy.

questions.question: A train travels across a flat plain at high speed. What type(s) of energy does the train possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: On level ground, the train has kinetic energy (high speed) but negligible change in gravitational potential energy.

questions.question: A crane lifts a steel beam from the ground to a rooftop. What type(s) of energy does the beam possess during lifting?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: During lifting, the beam has kinetic energy (motion upward) and increasing gravitational potential energy.

questions.question: A ball stops at the base of a ramp. What type(s) of energy does the ball possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The stationary ball at the base has no kinetic energy and minimum gravitational potential energy.

questions.question: A waterfall plunges into the pool below at high speed. What type(s) of energy does the water possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The falling water has kinetic energy (high speed) and gravitational potential energy (height above pool).

questions.question: A skier descends a slope, gaining speed rapidly. What type(s) of energy does the skier possess?
options: Both gravitational potential and kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The descending skier has gravitational potential energy (height) and increasing kinetic energy (accelerating).

questions.question: A ball is dropped from the top of a building. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: As the ball falls, kinetic energy increases (accelerating) and potential energy decreases (losing height).

questions.question: A box slides down a frictionless ramp. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: On a frictionless ramp, potential energy converts entirely to kinetic energy as the box descends.

questions.question: A weight is lifted vertically upward by a pulley with a constant velocity. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means kinetic energy is constant, while potential energy increases with height.

questions.question: A skier accelerates as they descend a slope. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: Descending and accelerating means kinetic energy increases while potential energy decreases.

questions.question: A pendulum swings from its highest point toward the lowest point. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: As the pendulum descends, potential energy converts to kinetic energy.

questions.question: A car comes to a stop at a red light. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: Stopping on level ground decreases kinetic energy to zero while potential energy remains constant.

questions.question: A rock is thrown straight up into the air. Select the two correct statements about energy changes during ascent:
questions.explanation: During upward motion, kinetic energy decreases (slowing down) and potential energy increases (gaining height).

questions.question: A child swings on a swing set and is momentarily at the highest point. Select the two correct statements about energy changes as the child approaches the highest point:
questions.explanation: At the highest point, kinetic energy is minimum (decreasing to zero) and potential energy is maximum (increasing).

questions.question: An airplane takes off, climbing steadily upward at a constant acceleration. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: Accelerating upward increases both kinetic energy (gaining speed) and potential energy (gaining altitude).

questions.question: A boulder rests motionlessly on the edge of a cliff. Select the two correct statements about energy changes:
questions.explanation: The stationary boulder has constant kinetic energy (zero) and constant potential energy (fixed height).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent understanding of energy types and transformations!
scoreMessages.70: Good grasp of energy concepts - review specific scenarios.
scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding - practice identifying energy changes in different situations.
scoreMessages.0: Review fundamental concepts of kinetic and potential energy.
